### Article One
The Unified System (Law) for International Land Transport between the Cooperation Council for the Arab States of the Gulf, the text of which is attached to this Decree-Law, is hereby approved.

### Article Two
The Kuwaiti Dinar <orig>الدينار الكويتي</orig> shall be equated to the Saudi Riyal <orig>الريال السعودي</orig> according to the exchange rate announced by the Central Bank on the day the administrative penalty (financial fine) is issued.

### Article Three
Any provision that contravenes or conflicts with the provisions of this System (Law) is hereby repealed.

### Article Four
The ministers, each within their respective jurisdictions, shall implement this Decree-Law, and it shall come into force from the date of its publication in the Official Gazette.

## The Unified System (Law) for International Land Transport between the Cooperation Council for the Arab States of the Gulf
### Article One
### Definitions
For the purposes of applying the provisions of this System (Law), the following words and phrases shall have the meanings assigned to each of them, unless the context requires otherwise:
1 – Cooperation Council: The Cooperation Council for the Arab States of the Gulf.
2 – Council States: The states of the Cooperation Council.
3 – Supreme Council: The Supreme Council of the Cooperation Council.
4 – The State: A member state of the Cooperation Council.
5 – The System (Law): The Unified System (Law) for International Land Transport between the Cooperation Council for the Arab States of the Gulf.
6 – The Regulations: The executive regulations of this System (Law).
7 – The Ministerial Committee: The committee of ministers concerned with transport and communications affairs in the Council States.
8 – The Competent Authority: The ministry or entity responsible for implementing the provisions of the System (Law) in the State.
9 – Head of the Competent Authority: The minister or head of the competent authority.
10 – International Land Transport: The activity of transporting passengers or goods, or both, for a fee, or on a commercial basis, on land roads between the Council States.
11 – Means of Transport: Any vehicle (bus, car, single truck, tractor and trailer, tractor and semi-trailer, or any other combination) registered or licensed in any of the Council States.

12 - State of Registration: The state in which the means of transport is registered.
13 - Carrier: The natural or legal person licensed by the Competent Authority to engage in international land transport.
14 - Driver: The natural person operating the means of transport.
15 - Passenger: The natural person present in the means of transport by virtue of an agreement with the carrier for the purpose of travel, other than the driver.
16 - Goods: Any materials, equipment, commodities, animals, or other items.
17 - Operating Card: The document issued by the Competent Authority under which a means of transport is licensed to operate in international land transport.
18 - Permit: The authorization issued by the Competent Authority under which a means of transport is permitted to enter the state empty, for the purpose of transport from specific points within that state to its state of registration, or for transport to another state other than its state of registration.
19 - Transport Document: A document issued by the carrier to the natural or legal person contracted with it as the consignor, owner of the goods, or their authorized representative, in accordance with the transport contract concluded between them for its transport to the consignee. It is considered proof of the carrier's receipt of the goods subject to transport in the condition indicated in the document.
20 - Exceptional Load: Indivisible goods and the means of transport, whose gross weight and/or overall dimensions exceed the weights or dimensions specified in the approved standard specifications.
21 - Hazardous Materials: Any solid, liquid, or gaseous substance, whether natural or manufactured, that poses a danger to the environment or any of its elements, or to the health of humans and living organisms due to its toxicity, flammability, explosiveness, or corrosiveness.

## Article Two
### Objective and Scope
1 - This System (Law) aims to regulate international land transport among the Council states and to raise the level of road safety.
2 - The provisions of this System (Law) and its Regulations shall apply to international land transport among the Council states.

## Article Three
### Operating Card
A means of transport may not engage in international land transport without first obtaining an Operating Card. The Regulations shall specify the types of activities and the minimum data required on the card.

## Article Four
### Return Trip Transport and Empty Entry
1 - A means of transport may—after dropping off passengers or unloading goods in a state other than its state of registration—engage in international land transport from that state only to its state of registration on the return trip, in accordance with the conditions and controls specified by the Regulations.
2 - A means of transport may enter any of the Council states other than its state of registration empty for the purpose of transit, in accordance with the conditions and controls specified by the Regulations.
3 - A means of transport may not enter any of the Council states other than its state of registration empty for the purpose of engaging in international land transport without first obtaining a permit from the state from which the transport is intended, in accordance with the conditions and controls specified by the Regulations.
4 - Subject to the provision of paragraph (1) of this Article, a means of transport may not engage in international land transport originating from a state other than its state of registration without first obtaining a permit from the state from which the transport is intended, in accordance with the conditions and controls specified by the Regulations.

## Article Five
### Unregistered Means of Transport
A means of transport not registered in any of the Council states may not engage in international land transport to a state other than its state of registration, except after obtaining approval from the Competent Authority in the state from which the transport is intended. The Regulations shall specify the necessary conditions and controls for this.

## Article Six
### Domestic Transport of Passengers and Goods
A means of transport is prohibited from transporting passengers or goods between two points within a state other than its state of registration, except with the approval of the Competent Authority and in accordance with the systems (laws) in force in that state.

## Article Seven
### Technical Conditions and Specifications for Means of Transport
The Regulations shall specify the technical conditions and specifications that must be met by means of transport, in a manner that ensures the safety of transport operations on the road network.

## Article Eight
### Transport of Goods
1 - The transport of goods whose import, export, or transit is prohibited by the state in accordance with the systems (laws) in force in that state is forbidden.
2 - The transport of goods and hazardous materials is forbidden without adhering to the systems (laws), regulations, instructions, and standard specifications approved by the Competent Authority.
3 - The transport of weapons, fireworks, military equipment, or explosives and the materials used in their manufacture, from one state to another, is forbidden, except with the approval of the Competent Authority and in accordance with the systems (laws) and instructions in force in the state to and from which the transport is intended.

# Article Nine
## Exceptional Load
The transport of an exceptional load is prohibited without obtaining approval from the competent authority in the state to which the transport is intended. The regulations shall specify the necessary conditions and controls for this.

# Article Ten
## Carrier's Obligations
When conducting international land transport, the carrier shall be obligated to the following:
1 - Keep the operating card inside the means of transport.
2 - Ensure that passengers and drivers carry valid official (legal) travel documents.
3 - Issue a list of passengers' names when transporting passengers, as specified by the regulations, and keep it inside the means of transport.
4 - Do not load any personal luggage or movables—of any kind—in the means of transport designated for passenger transport without their owners accompanying them.
5 - Place a tag on the personal luggage or movables of passengers. The regulations shall specify the specifications of the tag and the data recorded on it.
6 - Use the appropriate means of transport for the type of goods being transported and load them in a safe manner.
7 - Issue the transport document in accordance with the procedures and controls specified by the regulations.
8 - Adhere to the technical conditions and specifications required for the means of transport.
9 - Adhere to the gross weight, maximum weight per axle, and overall dimensions permitted for the means of transport to travel on the road network.
10 - Any other obligations specified by the regulations.
Should the carrier breach any of these obligations, the competent authority has the right to prevent the violating means of transport from entering or transiting its territory, in accordance with the prevention mechanism specified by the regulations.

# Article Eleven
## Driver's Obligations
When conducting international land transport, the driver shall be obligated to the following:
1 - Enter through the official ports of the state.
2 - Travel on the routes and roads permitted for travel within the state's territory.
3 - Stop for rest in the designated areas within the state's territory.
4 - Unload goods in their designated places.
5 - Adhere to the driving and rest hours as specified by the regulations.
6 - Any other obligations specified by the regulations.

# Article Twelve
## Duration of Stay
The means of transport is prohibited from exceeding the specified duration of stay—according to the purpose of entry—within the state. The regulations shall specify the cases in which the duration of stay may be exceeded and the procedures to be followed in such cases.

# Article Thirteen
## Weights and Dimensions of the Means of Transport
1 - It is prohibited to exceed the gross weight, the maximum weight per axle, or the overall dimensions (length, width, and height) permitted for the means of transport to travel on the state's road network, as specified in the approved standard specifications.
2 - It is prohibited for a means of transport designated for carrying goods to bypass the weight and dimension measurement stations located on the state's road network without approval from the competent authority.

# Article Fourteen
## Violations and Administrative Penalties
The competent authority is responsible for imposing administrative penalties for the violations stipulated in this system (law).

# Article Fifteen
1 - Anyone who violates any of Articles (Four, Seven, Eleven, or Twelve) of this system (law) shall be penalized with a financial (administrative) fine of not less than (1,000) one thousand Saudi Riyals and not more than (5,000) five thousand Saudi Riyals (or its equivalent in the currencies of the Council states).
2 - Anyone who violates any of Articles (Five, Eight, or Nine) of this system (law) shall be penalized with a financial (administrative) fine of not less than (5,000) five thousand Saudi Riyals and not more than (20,000) twenty thousand Saudi Riyals (or its equivalent in the currencies of the Council states).
3 - Anyone who violates either of Articles (Three or Six) of this system (law) shall be penalized with a financial (administrative) fine of not less than (20,000) twenty thousand Saudi Riyals and not more than (100,000) one hundred thousand Saudi Riyals (or its equivalent in the currencies of the Council states).

# Article Sixteen
Anyone who violates Article (Thirteen) of this system (law) shall be penalized as follows:
1 - A financial (administrative) fine of not less than (100) one hundred Saudi Riyals and not more than (1,000) one thousand Saudi Riyals (or its equivalent in the currencies of the Council states), in the case of exceeding the permitted gross weight for the means of transport to travel## Article Twenty-One
### Fees and Taxes
A means of transport registered in the Council states shall be treated as a national means of transport with regard to fees, taxes, and service charges.

## Article Twenty-Two
### Recording of Violations
Employees of the Competent Authority may be granted the capacity of judicial police officers in the implementation of the provisions of this System (Law) and its Regulations, in accordance with the procedures followed in the State.

## Article Twenty-Three
### Application of the System (Law) and Regulations
The Competent Authority in each State shall take all necessary statutory (legal) measures to ensure the application of the provisions of the System (Law) and its Regulations.

## Article Twenty-Four
### The Regulations
The Competent Authority shall issue the Regulations – in accordance with the procedures followed in each State – after their approval by the Ministerial Committee, and the same procedures shall apply to their amendment.

## Article Twenty-Five
### Entry into Force of the System (Law)
This System (Law) shall be approved by the Supreme Council and shall be implemented on a mandatory basis in accordance with the constitutional procedures of each State.

# Explanatory Memorandum
## to Decree-Law No. 140 of 2025
### Issuing the Unified System (Law) for International Road Transport among the Cooperation Council for the Arab States of the Gulf
Stemming from the objectives of the Basic Statute of the Cooperation Council for the Arab States of the Gulf, which calls for closer convergence and stronger ties among the member states, and in line with the objectives of the Unified Economic Agreement among the Cooperation Council for the Arab States of the Gulf, which aims to strengthen and develop economic relations and cooperation among the member states, strive for advanced stages of economic integration, and establish similar legislation and legal foundations in the economic and financial fields, and out of the keenness of Their Majesties and Highnesses, the leaders of the GCC states, to enhance everything that would regulate international road transport operations among the member states and raise the level of road safety.
And whereas this System (Law) was issued to keep pace with the Council's progress towards unifying laws and regulations among the member states, the Supreme Council of the Cooperation Council for the Arab States of the Gulf, in its forty-third session held in

transport on the State's road network, for every (100) one hundred kilograms – or any part thereof – that exceeds the gross weight by more than (200) two hundred kilograms.
2 – A financial (administrative) fine of not less than (1,000) one thousand Saudi Riyals and not more than (2,000) two thousand Saudi Riyals (or its equivalent in the currencies of the Council states) for each exceeding axle that is more than (100) one hundred kilograms over the maximum permissible axle weight for the means of transport to travel on the State's road network. The provision of this paragraph shall apply in the event that the means of transport does not exceed the gross weight permitted for travel on the State's road network.
3 – A financial (administrative) fine of not less than (1,000) one thousand Saudi Riyals and not more than (5,000) five thousand Saudi Riyals (or its equivalent in the currencies of the Council states) for exceeding any of the overall dimensions (length, width, height) permitted for the means of transport to travel on the State's road network.
4 – A financial (administrative) fine of not less than (2,000) two thousand Saudi Riyals and not more than (10,000) ten thousand Saudi Riyals (or its equivalent in the currencies of the Council states) when a means of transport bypasses weight and dimension measurement stations located on the State's road network without approval from the Competent Authority.

## Article Seventeen
### Repetition of the Violation
Without prejudice to Articles (Fifteen and Sixteen), the value of the fine for a violation shall be doubled if it is repeated within (one year) from the date of its commission, provided it does not exceed its maximum limit.

## Article Eighteen
### Payment of Financial Fines
The State in which any violation of the provisions of this System (Law) has occurred may take the legal measures that guarantee the payment of the fines resulting from these violations.

## Article Nineteen
### Prohibition of Entry or Transit
In the event that the means of transport or the driver violates the provisions of any of Articles (Eight, Nine, or Thirteen) of this System (Law), the competent judicial or administrative authority, as the case may be, may impose a penalty prohibiting the means of transport, the driver, or both from entering or transiting the territory of that State for a period not exceeding two years.

## Article Twenty
### Grievance
Any person aggrieved by the decisions issued in application of the provisions of this System (Law) may file a grievance with the Competent Authority in accordance with the systems (laws) in force in the State.

Riyadh, Kingdom of Saudi Arabia <orig>المملكة العربية السعودية</orig>, on 15 Jumada al-Awwal 1444 H, corresponding to December 9, 2022, on the Unified System (Law) for International Land Transport between the Cooperation Council for the Arab States of the Gulf <orig>مجلس التعاون لدول الخليج العربية</orig>, the provisions of which are set out in twenty-five articles.
Article One addressed the definitions of words and phrases mentioned in the context of the System's (Law's) provisions. Article Two defined its objective, which is to regulate international land transport among the Council states and to raise the level of road safety. This article also specified the scope of its provisions, as they apply to international land transport among the Council states.
Article Three mandated that the means of transport obtain an operating card, stipulating that the executive regulations of this law shall specify the types of activities and the minimum data required on the card.
Article Four explained the provisions for return transport and empty entry, and referred to the executive regulations for the determination of conditions and controls.
Article Five prohibited a means of transport not registered in any of the Council states from practicing international land transport to a state other than its state of registration, except after obtaining approval from the competent authority in the state from which the transport is intended. It referred to the executive regulations for the determination of conditions and controls.
Article Six prohibited the practice of domestic transport of passengers and goods except after obtaining approval from the competent authority and in accordance with the regulations in force in that state.
Article Seven referred to the executive regulations for the determination of the technical conditions and specifications for the means of transport.
Article Eight clarified the provisions for the transport of goods between the Cooperation Council states. It prohibited the transport of goods that the state forbids from being imported, exported, or transited in accordance with its laws. It also prohibited the transport of dangerous goods and materials without following the regulations approved by the competent authority. It prohibited the transport of weapons, fireworks, military equipment, explosives, and materials used in their manufacture from one state to another except after obtaining approval from the competent authority and in accordance with the systems (laws) in force in the state to and from which the transport is intended.
Article Nine prohibited the transport of exceptional loads without obtaining approval from the competent authority in the state to which the transport is intended, and it referred to the executive regulations for the necessary conditions and controls.
Articles Ten and Eleven, respectively, addressed the obligations of both the carrier and the driver when practicing land transport.
Meanwhile, Article Twelve prohibited the means of transport from exceeding the specified period of stay and its entry within the state, and referred to the executive regulations for cases in which the period of stay may be exceeded and the procedures to be followed in such cases.
Article Thirteen clarified the special provisions for the weights and dimensions of the means of transport.
Articles Fourteen, Fifteen, and Sixteen stipulated the violations contained in this System (Law) and the administrative penalties imposed by the competent authority.
Article Seventeen addressed the provision for repeat violations, stating that the value of the fine for the violation shall be doubled if it is repeated within one (1) year from the date of its commission, not to exceed its maximum limit.
Article Eighteen permitted the state in which any violation of the provisions of this System (Law) occurred to take the legal measures that guarantee the payment of the financial fines resulting from these violations.
Article Nineteen also permitted the competent judicial or administrative authority, as the case may be, to impose a penalty of banning the means of transport, the driver, or both from entering or transiting the territories of that state for a period not exceeding two years, in the event that the means of transport or the driver violates the provisions of any of Articles Eight, Nine, or Thirteen of this System (Law).
Article Twenty stipulated the right of the aggrieved party to appeal decisions issued in application of the provisions of this System (Law). The appeal shall be made to the competent authority in accordance with the systems (laws) in force in the state.
Article Twenty-One decreed that a means of transport registered in the Council states shall be treated as a national means of transport with regard to fees, taxes, and service charges.
Article Twenty-Two permitted granting employees of the competent authority the capacity of judicial police in implementing the provisions of this System (Law) in accordance with the procedures followed in the state.
Article Twenty-Three obligated the competent authority in each state to take all necessary legal measures to apply the provisions of the System (Law) and its executive regulations.
Article Twenty-Four required the competent authority to issue the executive regulations for this System (Law) after their approval by the Ministerial Committee, in accordance with the procedures followed in each state.
Article Twenty-Five explained how the System (Law) shall come into force.
The Unified System (Law) for International Land Transport between the Cooperation Council for the Arab States of the Gulf <orig>مجلس التعاون لدول الخليج العربية</orig>, after reviewing the Basic Statute of the Cooperation Council for the Arab States of the Gulf, and the Unified Economic Agreement between the Cooperation Council for the Arab States of the Gulf, and based on the recommendation of the Ministers of Transport and Communications in their twenty-first meeting held on November 29, 2018, in the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig>, and stemming from the keenness of Their Majesties and Highnesses, the leaders of the Cooperation Council states, to document and develop economic relations and cooperation among the Council states, and to enhance everything that would regulate international land transport operations among the Council states and raise the level of road safety.
<page_end>6</page_end>

The Supreme Council of the Cooperation Council for the Arab States of the Gulf, in its (43rd) session held in Riyadh, Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, on 15 Jumada al-Awwal 1444 H, corresponding to December 9, 2022, approved the Unified System (Law) for International Land Transport between the Cooperation Council for the Arab States of the Gulf, the text of which follows:

## Article One
## Definitions
For the purposes of applying the provisions of this System (Law), the following words and phrases shall have the meanings indicated opposite each, unless the context requires otherwise:
1. Cooperation Council: The Cooperation Council for the Arab States of the Gulf.
2. Council States: The member states of the Cooperation Council.
3. Supreme Council: The Supreme Council of the Cooperation Council.
4. The State: A member state of the Cooperation Council.
5. The System (Law): The Unified System (Law) for International Land Transport in the Cooperation Council for the Arab States of the Gulf.
6. The Regulations: The executive regulations of this System (Law).
7. The Ministerial Committee: The committee of ministers concerned with transport and communications affairs in the Council States.
8. The Competent Authority <orig>السلطة المختصة</orig>: The ministry or body responsible for implementing the provisions of the System (Law) in the State.
9. Head of the Competent Authority: The minister or head of the Competent Authority.
10. International Land Transport: The activity of transporting passengers or goods, or both, for a fee or on a commercial basis on land roads between the Council States.
11. Means of Transport: Any vehicle (bus, car, single truck, tractor and trailer, tractor and semi-trailer, or any other combination) registered or licensed in any of the Council States.
12. State of Registration: The state in which the means of transport is registered.
13. The Carrier <orig>الناقل</orig>: The natural or legal person licensed by the Competent Authority to engage in international land transport.
14. The Driver: The natural person operating the means of transport.
15. The Passenger: The natural person present in the means of transport by virtue of an agreement with the carrier for the purpose of travel, other than the driver.
16. Goods: Any materials, equipment, commodities, animals, or others.
17. Operating Card <orig>بطاقة التشغيل</orig>: The document issued by the Competent Authority under which a means of transport is licensed to operate in international land transport.
18. The Permit <orig>التصريح</orig>: The authorization issued by the Competent Authority under which a means of transport is permitted to enter the State empty for the purpose of transport from specific points within that State to its state of registration, or for transport to a state other than its state of registration.
19. Transport Document <orig>وثيقة النقل</orig>: A document issued by the carrier to the natural or legal person contracting with them as the consignor, owner of the goods, or their authorized representative, in accordance with the transport contract concluded between them for its transport to a consignee, and it is considered proof of the carrier's receipt of the goods subject to transport in the condition stated in the document.
20. Exceptional Load <orig>الحمولة الاستثنائية</orig>: Indivisible goods and the means of transport, whose total weight and/or overall dimensions exceed the weights or dimensions specified in the approved standard specifications.
21. Hazardous Materials: Any solid, liquid, or gaseous substance, whether natural or manufactured, that poses a danger to the environment or any of its elements, or to the health of humans and living organisms due to its toxicity, flammability, explosiveness, or corrosiveness.

## Article Two
## Objective and Scope
1. The System (Law) aims to regulate international land transport between the Council States and to raise the level of road safety.
2. The provisions of this System (Law) and the Regulations shall apply to international land transport between the Council States.

## Article Three
## Operating Card
A means of transport may not engage in international land transport except after obtaining an Operating Card. The Regulations shall specify the types of activities and the minimum data required to be included on the card.

## Article Four
## Transport on the Return Trip and Empty Entry
1. A means of transport may—after dropping off passengers or unloading goods in a state other than its state of registration—engage in international land transport from that state only to its state of registration on the return trip, in accordance with the conditions and controls specified by the Regulations.
2. A means of transport may enter any of the Council States other than its state of registration empty for the purpose of transit, in accordance with the conditions and controls specified by the Regulations.
3. A means of transport may not enter any of the Council States other than its state of registration empty for the purpose of engaging in international land transport except after obtaining a Permit from the state from which transport is intended, in accordance with the conditions and controls specified by the Regulations.
4. Subject to the provision of paragraph (1) of this Article, a means of transport may not

## Article Five
### Unregistered Means of Transport
An unregistered means of transport in any of the Council states may not engage in international land transport to a state other than its state of registration, except after obtaining approval from the competent authority in the state from which the transport is intended. The Regulations shall specify the necessary conditions and controls for this.

## Article Six
### Domestic Transport of Passengers and Goods
A means of transport is prohibited from transporting passengers or goods between two points within a state other than its state of registration, except with the approval of the competent authority and in accordance with the systems (laws) in force in that state.

## Article Seven
### Technical Conditions and Specifications for the Means of Transport
The Regulations shall specify the technical conditions and specifications that must be met by means of transport, in a manner that ensures the safety of transport operations on the road network.

## Article Eight
### Transport of Goods
1. It is prohibited to transport goods whose import, export, or transit is forbidden by the state in accordance with the systems (laws) in force in that state.
2. It is prohibited to transport hazardous goods and materials without adhering to the systems (laws), regulations, instructions, and standard specifications approved by the competent authority.
3. It is prohibited to transport weapons, fireworks, military equipment, or explosives and the materials used in their manufacture, from one state to another, except with the approval of the competent authority and in accordance with the systems (laws) and instructions in force in the state to and from which the transport is intended.

## Article Nine
### Exceptional Loads
It is prohibited to transport exceptional loads without obtaining approval from the competent authority in the state to which the transport is intended. The Regulations shall specify the necessary conditions and controls for this.

## Article Ten
### Obligations of the Carrier
When engaging in international land transport, the carrier shall be obligated to the following:
1. Keep the operating card inside the means of transport.
2. Ensure that passengers and drivers carry valid official (legal) travel documents.
3. Issue a list of passengers' names when transporting passengers, as specified by the Regulations, and keep it inside the means of transport.
4. Not to load any personal luggage or movables—of any kind—in a means of transport designated for passengers without the owners' consent.
5. Place a tag on the personal luggage or movables of passengers. The Regulations shall specify the specifications of the tag and the data recorded on it.
6. Use a means of transport suitable for the type of goods being transported and load it in a safe manner.
7. Issue the transport document in accordance with the procedures and controls specified by the Regulations.
8. Adhere to the technical conditions and specifications that must be met by the means of transport.
9. Adhere to the gross weight, maximum axle weight, and overall dimensions permitted for the means of transport to travel on the road network.
10. Any other obligations specified by the Regulations.
Should the carrier breach any of these obligations, the competent authority has the right to prevent the violating means of transport from entering or transiting its territory, in accordance with the prevention mechanism specified by the Regulations.

## Article Eleven
### Obligations of the Driver
When engaging in international land transport, the driver shall be obligated to the following:
1. Enter through the official ports of the state.
2. Travel on the routes and roads permitted for travel within the state's territory.
3. Stop for rest in the designated areas within the state's territory.
4. Unload goods in their designated places.
5. Adhere to the driving and rest hours as specified by the Regulations.
6. Any other obligations specified by the Regulations.

## Article Twelve
### Duration of Stay
A means of transport is prohibited from exceeding the specified duration of stay—according to the purpose of entry—within the state. The Regulations shall specify the cases in which the duration of stay may be exceeded and the procedures to be followed in such cases.

## Article Thirteen
### Weights and Dimensions of the Means of Transport
1. It is prohibited to exceed the gross weight, maximum axle weight, or the overall dimensions (length, width, and height) permitted for the means of transport to travel on the state's road network, in accordance with the limits set by the approved standard specifications.
2. A means of transport designated for carrying goods is prohibited from bypassing the weight and dimension measurement stations located on the state's road network without approval from the competent authority.

# Article Fourteen
## Violations and Administrative Procedures
The Competent Authority shall be responsible for imposing administrative penalties for the violations stipulated in this System (Law).

# Article Fifteen
1. Anyone who violates any of Articles (Four, Seven, Eleven, or Twelve) of this System (Law) shall be penalized with a financial (administrative) fine of not less than (1,000) one thousand Saudi Riyals, and not more than (5,000) five thousand Saudi Riyals (or its equivalent in the currencies of the Council states).
2. Anyone who violates any of Articles (Five, Eight, or Nine) of this System (Law) shall be penalized with a financial (administrative) fine of not less than (5,000) five thousand Saudi Riyals, and not more than (20,000) twenty thousand Saudi Riyals (or its equivalent in the currencies of the Council states).
3. Anyone who violates either of Articles (Three or Six) of this System (Law) shall be penalized with a financial (administrative) fine of not less than (20,000) twenty thousand Saudi Riyals, and not more than (100,000) one hundred thousand Saudi Riyals (or its equivalent in the currencies of the Council states).

# Article Sixteen
Anyone who violates Article (Thirteen) of this System (Law) shall be penalized as follows:
1. A financial (administrative) fine of not less than (100) one hundred Saudi Riyals, and not more than (1,000) one thousand Saudi Riyals (or its equivalent in the currencies of the Council states), in the event the permitted gross weight for the vehicle's operation on the state's road network is exceeded, for every (100) one hundred kilograms – or any part thereof – that exceeds the gross weight by more than (200) two hundred kilograms.
2. A financial (administrative) fine of not less than (1,000) one thousand Saudi Riyals, and not more than (2,000) two thousand Saudi Riyals (or its equivalent in the currencies of the Council states) for each axle exceeding the maximum permitted axle weight for the vehicle's operation on the state's road network by more than (100) one hundred kilograms. The provision of this paragraph shall apply in the event the vehicle does not exceed the permitted gross weight for operation on the state's road network.
3. A financial (administrative) fine of not less than (1,000) one thousand Saudi Riyals, and not more than (5,000) five thousand Saudi Riyals (or its equivalent in the currencies of the Council states) upon exceeding any of the permitted overall dimensions (length, width, height) for the vehicle's operation on the state's road network.
4. A financial (administrative) fine of not less than (2,000) two thousand Saudi Riyals, and not more than (10,000) ten thousand Saudi Riyals (or its equivalent in the currencies of the Council states) when a vehicle bypasses weight and dimension measurement stations located on the state's road network without approval from the Competent Authority.

# Article Seventeen
## Repetition of Violation
Without prejudice to Articles (Fifteen and Sixteen), the value of the fine for a violation shall be doubled if it is repeated within (one year) from the date of its commission, provided it does not exceed its maximum limit.

# Article Eighteen
## Payment of Financial Fines
The state in which any violation of the provisions of this System (Law) occurs may take the legal measures that guarantee the payment of the fines resulting from these violations.

# Article Nineteen
## Prohibition of Entry or Transit
In the event a vehicle or driver violates the provisions of any of Articles (Eight, Nine, or Thirteen) of this System (Law), the competent judicial or administrative authority, as the case may be, may impose a penalty prohibiting the vehicle, the driver, or both from entering or transiting the territory of that state for a period not exceeding two years.

# Article Twenty
## Grievance
Anyone aggrieved by the decisions issued in application of the provisions of this System (Law) may file a grievance with the Competent Authority in accordance with the systems (laws) in force in the state.

# Article Twenty-One
## Fees and Taxes
A vehicle registered in the Council states shall be treated as a national vehicle with respect to fees, taxes, and service charges.

# Article Twenty-Two
## Recording of Violations
The employees of the Competent Authority may be granted the capacity of judicial enforcement officers in the implementation of the provisions of this System (Law) and its Regulations, in accordance with the procedures followed in the state.

# Article Twenty-Three
## Application of the System (Law) and Regulations
The Competent Authority in each state shall take all necessary statutory (legal) measures to ensure the application of the provisions of the System (Law) and its Regulations.

# Article Twenty-Four
## The Regulations
The Competent Authority shall issue the Regulations – in accordance with the procedures followed in each state – after their approval by the Ministerial Committee, and the same procedures shall apply to their amendment.

# Article Twenty-Five
## Entry into Force of the System (Law)
This System (Law) shall be approved by the Supreme Council and shall be implemented on a mandatory basis in accordance with the constitutional procedures of each state.

# Decree No. 188 of 2025
## Approving the Memorandum of Understanding between the Government of the State of Kuwait and the Government of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia for Financial Cooperation

- Having reviewed the Constitution,
- And the Amiri Order issued on 2 Dhu al-Qi'dah 1445 H, corresponding to 10 May 2024 AD,
- And upon the submission of the Minister of Foreign Affairs,
- And with the approval of the Council of Ministers,

**We have decreed the following**

### Article One
The Memorandum of Understanding between the Government of the State of Kuwait and the Government of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia for Financial Cooperation, signed in Kuwait City on 1/6/2025, the text of which is attached to this decree, is hereby approved.

### Article Two
The ministers, each within their respective jurisdiction, shall implement this decree, and it shall come into force from the date of its publication in the Official Gazette.

**Amir of Kuwait**
**Mishal Al-Ahmad Al-Jaber Al-Sabah <orig>مشعل الأحمد الجابر الصباح</orig>**

**Prime Minister**
**Ahmad Abdullah Al-Ahmad Al-Sabah <orig>أحمد عبد الله الأحمد الصباح</orig>**

**Minister of Foreign Affairs**
**Abdullah Ali Abdullah Al-Yahya <orig>عبد الله علي عبد الله اليحيا</orig>**

Issued at Seif Palace on: 1 Rabi' al-Thani 1447 H
Corresponding to: 23 September 2025 AD

# Memorandum of Understanding between the Government of the State of Kuwait and the Government of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia for Financial Cooperation

The Government of the State of Kuwait, represented by the Ministry of Finance, and the Government of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, represented by the Ministry of Finance (hereinafter referred to as "the two Parties"), proceeding from the agreements and regulations in force within the framework of the Cooperation Council for the Arab States of the Gulf, based on the principles of mutual trust, equality, partnership, and cooperation, recognizing the importance of exchanging expertise and information in the financial field for each Party to benefit from the other's experience, and desiring to enhance and strengthen the relations between them in this field, and in accordance with the regulations, laws, and instructions in force in both countries, and according to the available capabilities, have agreed as follows:

### Article One
This Memorandum aims to enhance and develop the relations between the two Parties and increase cooperation between them in the financial field, and to explore new opportunities to strengthen this cooperation on the basis of mutual benefit, in a manner that serves the common interests of their two countries.

### Article Two
The two Parties shall work on the following:
1- Enhancing joint coordination between them on regional and international issues in the financial field through international organizations and institutions.
2- Developing macroeconomic policies and analyzing public finance data.
3- Developing financial systems and legislation and their governance in the public sector.
4- Applying international statistical guides and methodologies.
5- Exchanging views and experiences in dealing with the financial repercussions of external shocks.
6- Exchanging on climate change topics directly related to financial policies.
7- Benefiting from experiences and expertise in the field of public debt.
8- Any other field agreed upon by the two Parties.

### Article Three
The implementation of cooperation between the two Parties shall be through the following means:
1- Exchanging expertise on national policies at the financial level to keep pace with global economic developments.
2- Capacity building and exchanging visits between experts and specialists.
3- Exchanging available information and data related to the financial sector.
4- Organizing seminars, conferences, and work sessions.
5- Any other means agreed upon by the two Parties.

### Article Four
Each Party shall appoint, in writing, a liaison officer who will undertake the tasks of communication and coordination regarding the implementation of what is stated in this Memorandum. The contact details of the liaison officer shall be exchanged between the two Parties through diplomatic channels. In the event of a change of the liaison officer, the other Party shall be notified thereof.

## Article Five
Each party shall take the necessary measures to protect the intellectual property rights resulting within the framework of this Memorandum, in light of its applicable regulations and laws, and the international agreements to which it is a party.

## Article Six
Each party shall bear the costs of implementing its respective areas of cooperation mentioned in this Memorandum, in accordance with its available resources.

## Article Seven
The two parties undertake that the information and documents exchanged between them shall only be used for the purposes designated for them as agreed upon, and shall not be transferred to a third party or used for administrative, judicial, or editorial purposes without the written consent of the party that provided them.

## Article Eight
Any dispute arising from the interpretation, application, or implementation of this Memorandum shall be settled through direct communication between the two parties. In the event that an agreement is not reached, the dispute shall be settled through diplomatic channels, and it may not be submitted to any court, authority, or any other entity for settlement.

## Article Nine
1 – This Memorandum shall enter into force from the date of the last mutual notification between the two parties through diplomatic channels, confirming the completion of the necessary internal regulatory procedures for its entry into force.
2 – The term of this Memorandum is (five) years and shall be automatically renewed for a similar period or periods, unless one party notifies the other in writing – through diplomatic channels – of its desire to terminate or not renew it at least (six) months prior to the specified termination date.
3 – This Memorandum may be amended by written agreement of the two parties, and the amendment shall enter into force in accordance with the procedure stipulated in paragraph (1) of this Article.
4 – In the event of the expiration or termination of this Memorandum, its provisions shall remain in effect with respect to the projects, programs, and activities that arose under it, unless the two parties agree otherwise.

This Memorandum was signed in the city of Kuwait on 5/12/1446 H, corresponding to 1/6/2025 G, in two original copies in the Arabic language.

Whereas the aforementioned judgment was published in the Official Gazette – Kuwait Today / Al-Kuwait Al-Youm <orig>الكويت اليوم</orig> – Issue 1714, Year Seventy, on 24/11/2024.

And whereas it has been established from the review of the certificate from the Court of Appeal's clerk's office that no appeal was filed against the aforementioned judgment up to the date of 16/2/2025.

And whereas the bankruptcy judge issued his decision dated 6/4/2025, assigning the bankruptcy trustee to prepare a provisional list of debts for the bankrupt parties.

And whereas the bankruptcy trustee submitted the letters dated 8/5/2025 and 7/9/2025, requesting authorization to sell the shares owned by the bankrupt company in Kuwait Projects Company (Holding) and The First for Local Fuel Marketing Company, noting that the proceeds from the sale of these shares are insufficient to cover the bankruptcy expenses due to the lack of other funds for the bankrupt company. The bankruptcy trustee attached to his aforementioned letters a statement listing the bankrupt company's creditors with a total debt of KWD 266,293.

And whereas the bankruptcy judge issued his decision dated 1/6/2025, assigning the bankruptcy trustee to submit documents proving the lack of funds owned by the bankrupt company, and to provide a statement of all funds owned by each of the bankrupt parties: 1- Mohammed Ali Hamad Al-Shammari <orig>محمد علي حمد الشمري</orig>, 2- Shalwa Dkhan Ajil <orig>شلوى دخان عجيل</orig>, and to clarify the role of the aforementioned bankrupt parties in the lack of sufficient funds in the bankrupt company to settle its debts.

And whereas the bankruptcy trustee submitted his letter dated 18/6/2025, titled "Final Bankruptcy Report," which states that the total outstanding debt owed by all bankrupt parties is an amount of KWD 283,526 (two hundred eighty-three thousand, five hundred and twenty-six Kuwaiti Dinars <orig>دينار كويتي</orig>), in addition to a debt to the Kuwait Credit Bank of KWD 41,814 (forty-one thousand, eight hundred and fourteen Kuwaiti Dinars <orig>دينار كويتي</orig>) secured by a mortgage on the property located in the Al-Andalus <orig>الأندلس</orig> area, Plot 5 <orig>قطعة 5</orig>, Parcel 17 <orig>قسيمة 17</orig>, Plan No. 28085, with an area of 910 square meters, of which the bankrupt party, Mohammed Ali Al-Shammari <orig>محمد علي الشمري</orig>, owns a 50% share. The company holds a bank balance with Kuwait Finance House of KWD 250, and a collection of shares and dividend checks as follows: 2,240 shares in Kuwait Projects Company (Holding) and 499 shares in The First for Local Fuel Marketing Company with an approximate total value of KWD 491, and 49 bonus shares in The First for Local Fuel Marketing Company, and cash dividend checks with a total value of KWD 138. The report concluded with a request to close the bankruptcy due to insufficient funds to cover the bankruptcy expenses and debts.

And whereas the bankruptcy judge issued the decision dated 20/7/2025, requesting a statement of the procedures taken regarding the property, Document No. 5739/1992, located in the Al-Andalus <orig>الأندلس</orig> area, Plot 5 <orig>قطعة 5</orig>, Parcel 17 <orig>قسيمة 17</orig>, Plan No. 28085, with an area of 910 square meters, of which the bankrupt party, Mohammed Ali Al-Shammari <orig>محمد علي الشمري</orig>, owns a 50% share, and a statement of the funds remaining for the bankrupt party after enforcement, and to provide the supporting documents.

And whereas the bankruptcy trustee submitted his letter dated 27/7/2025, which confirms the issuance of the judgment in Case No. 2015/275/168 Sales/1 dated 30/11/2020, and its appeal No. 2020/3641 Civil/5 dated 20/1/2020, which ruled to terminate the proceedings for the sale of the aforementioned property.

## Legal Basis:
Whereas Articles (196/198) of the Bankruptcy Law No. 71 of 2020 stipulate that: "If bankruptcy proceedings are suspended due to insufficient funds before the ratification of the judicial composition, the bankruptcy judge may decide to close them. The consequence of closing the bankruptcy due to insufficient funds is that each creditor regains the right to take individual actions and file individual lawsuits. If the creditor's debt has been verified and finally accepted in the bankruptcy, they may enforce it against the debtor in accordance with the provisions of Article (195) of this law. The bankruptcy trustee shall be responsible for a period of one year from the date of the bankruptcy's closure for the documents delivered to him by the creditors."

The Bankruptcy Administration must publish, announce, and register the decision to close the bankruptcy within ten days from the date of its issuance.

## Therefore, we have decided the following:
To close the bankruptcy of the bankrupt parties: 1- Mohammed Ali Hamad Al-Shammari <orig>محمد علي حمد الشمري</orig>. 2- Shalwa Dkhan Ajil <orig>شلوى دخان عجيل</orig>. 3- Al-Sitteen Al-Alamiya for General Trading and Contracting Company / Mohammed Ali Hamad Al-Shammari and his partner – a general partnership, due to the insufficiency of their funds. The Bankruptcy Administration shall notify the concerned parties of the decision, register it in the Commercial Register of the aforementioned company, and publish it in the Official Gazette.

Clerk of the Court
Bankruptcy Judge

Submitted by: Combined Group Contracting Company <orig>شركة المجموعة المشتركة للمقاولات</orig>.
Against: Al-Ma'rouf & Al-Barjas United General Trading Company <orig>شركة المعروف والبرجس المشتركة للتجارة العامة</orig>.
Bankruptcy Judge <orig>قاضي الإفلاس</orig>
In the name of His Highness the Amir of the State of Kuwait
Sheikh Mishal Al-Ahmad Al-Jaber Al-Sabah <orig>الشيخ مشعل الأحمد الجابر الصباح</orig>
Decision
On Monday, 8/9/2025, at the headquarters of the Bankruptcy Administration <orig>إدارة الإفلاس</orig>
With the membership of Mr. Zaid Abdul Hadi Al-Attar <orig>الأستاذ/ زيد عبد الهادي العطار</orig>, Bankruptcy Judge <orig>قاضي الإفلاس</orig>
And in the presence of Mr. Khalid Abdullah Al-Qubaisi <orig>الأستاذ/ خالد عبد الله القبيسي</orig>, Secretary <orig>أمين السر</orig>
In Application No. (1/2024 Restructuring <orig>إعادة هيكلة</orig>)
Registered under automated number: 241562490
Submitted by: Combined Group Contracting Company <orig>شركة المجموعة المشتركة للمقاولات</orig>
Against: Al-Ma'rouf & Al-Barjas United General Trading Company <orig>شركة المعروف والبرجس المشتركة للتجارة العامة</orig>
After reviewing the documents and the Inspector's <orig>المفتش</orig> letter dated 31/8/2025 requesting an extension of the inspection mission, and in accordance with the provisions of the Bankruptcy Law <orig>قانون الإفلاس</orig> and its Executive Regulations <orig>لائحته التنفيذية</orig>:
The facts are established by what was encompassed in the decision of the Bankruptcy Judge <orig>قاضي الإفلاس</orig> in the present application, issued on 15/6/2025, appointing the Inspector <orig>المفتش</orig> to perform the tasks set forth in the decision, to which we refer to avoid repetition.
Whereas the text of Article 1 of the Bankruptcy Law <orig>قانون الإفلاس</orig> states that "The Inspector <orig>المفتش</orig>:
A person licensed to carry out the duties of a Trustee <orig>الأمين</orig> who conducts inspections of all the debtor's business and records, or inspects specific operations or facts and submits a report thereon." And the text of Article (51) of the same law states that "The Bankruptcy Judge <orig>قاضي الإفلاس</orig> may, upon a reasoned request submitted by the Bankruptcy Committee <orig>لجنة الإفلاس</orig>, a regulatory body, a creditor, the Observer <orig>المراقب</orig>, the Trustee <orig>الأمين</orig>, or on his own initiative, appoint an Inspector <orig>المفتش</orig> from among the persons who are permitted to carry out the duties of a Trustee <orig>الأمين</orig> or from others, and assign him to inspect all of the debtor's business, assets, or dispositions, or to inspect a specific fact or facts, whenever the request for the appointment of the Inspector <orig>المفتش</orig> relates to a debtor for whose debts an application to initiate proceedings has been filed in accordance with the provisions of this Law. In the event a Trustee <orig>الأمين</orig> or an Observer <orig>المراقب</orig> is appointed, the Trustee <orig>الأمين</orig> or the Observer <orig>المراقب</orig>, as the case may be, shall undertake the inspection mission. The Bankruptcy Judge <orig>قاضي الإفلاس</orig> shall decide on the application within ten days from the date of its submission to the Bankruptcy Administration <orig>إدارة الإفلاس</orig>. The decision appointing the Inspector <orig>المفتش</orig> shall specify the mission entrusted to him, his competencies, powers, and fees, if he is not one of those appointed as a Trustee <orig>الأمين</orig> or Observer <orig>المراقب</orig>. In this case, the provisions of Articles (34, 35) of this Law shall apply to him. The Bankruptcy Judge <orig>قاضي الإفلاس</orig> may authorize the Inspector <orig>المفتش</orig> to seek assistance from whomever he deems necessary to accomplish the mission entrusted to him. Article (49) of this Law shall apply to the Inspector's <orig>المفتش</orig> fees. The Bankruptcy Judge <orig>قاضي الإفلاس</orig> may require the creditor who requested the inspection to pay such fees in advance, to be recovered from the debtor's assets if the Inspector <orig>المفتش</orig> concludes that the facts on which the creditor based the inspection request are valid." And the text of Article (52) thereof states that "The Inspector <orig>المفتش</orig>, in the course of carrying out the mission assigned to him, may request to hear the testimony of any person without an oath. He may also request any information or documents from the debtor, any of the creditors, units subject to the Central Bank <orig>البنك المركزي</orig>, persons licensed by the Authority <orig>الهيئة</orig>, regulatory bodies, or any other governmental or non-governmental entity.
If the aforementioned person or entity deems that such testimony, information, or documents are not relevant to the mission assigned to the Inspector <orig>المفتش</orig>, he must submit a request to the Bankruptcy Judge <orig>قاضي الإفلاس</orig> within ten days from the date of being notified of the Inspector's <orig>المفتش</orig> request, seeking exemption from all or part of what the Inspector <orig>المفتش</orig> has requested. The Bankruptcy Judge <orig>قاضي الإفلاس</orig> shall issue his decision on the request within ten days from the date of its submission, and his decision shall be final." And the text of Article (53) states that "The Inspector <orig>المفتش</orig> must complete the mission he is assigned to carry out and submit a report to the Bankruptcy Administration <orig>إدارة الإفلاس</orig> explaining how it was executed and the results he reached, within the deadlines specified in his appointment decision. The Bankruptcy Judge <orig>قاضي الإفلاس</orig> may extend the execution of the mission upon the Inspector's <orig>المفتش</orig> request."
Guided by the foregoing, and as the appointed Inspector <orig>المفتش</orig> has requested approval for an extension of the inspection mission assigned to him for an additional two months to enable him to complete his mission and execute it in the fullest manner, due to the vast volume of data and documents required to be examined for the period from 2013 to the present date, and the requirements of in-depth auditing, analysis, and evaluation that the mission entails, as the originally estimated period is insufficient to complete the required work optimally; and since granting the Inspector's <orig>المفتش</orig> request will enable him to accomplish the scope of his work in completing the inspection procedures and will serve the interests of the creditors and the present application, we therefore grant the Inspector's <orig>المفتش</orig> request by issuing the aforementioned extension decision.

Therefore, we have decided:
To extend the period of the inspection work established by the decision of the Bankruptcy Judge <orig>قاضي الإفلاس</orig> issued on 15/6/2025 for an additional two months, effective from the expiry date of the aforementioned previous decision. The Bankruptcy Administration <orig>إدارة الإفلاس</orig> shall publish this decision in the Official Gazette <orig>الجريدة الرسمية</orig>, record it in the Commercial Register <orig>السجل التجاري</orig>, and legally notify the concerned parties of this decision.
In accordance with Article (8) of the Bankruptcy Law <orig>قانون الإفلاس</orig>, decisions issued by the Bankruptcy Judge <orig>قاضي الإفلاس</orig> shall be considered enforceable instruments <orig>سندات تنفيذية</orig> under this Law. The Bankruptcy Administration <orig>إدارة الإفلاس</orig> shall affix the writ of execution <orig>الصيغة التنفيذية</orig> to them, and they shall be enforceable immediately upon issuance and without notification.

Secretary <orig>أمين السر</orig>
Bankruptcy Judge <orig>قاضي الإفلاس</orig>

## (Decision)
On Thursday, 11/9/2025, at the headquarters of the Bankruptcy Administration, with the membership of Mr. Omran Mohammed Al-Kandari <orig>عمران محمد الكندري</orig> and in the presence of Mr. Yousef Al-Bakr <orig>يوسف البكر</orig>.
In the Request/Case No. 3 / 2024 Preventive Settlement
Registered under automated number: 244194230
Submitted by: Penta Furniture and Furnishings Company W.L.L.
Against:
1- Kuwait Finance House <orig>بيت التمويل الكويتي</orig>
2- Ahli United Bank – currently Kuwait Finance House
3- Warba Bank <orig>بنك وربة</orig>
4- Al Mulla Finance Company <orig>شركة الملا للتمويل</orig>
5- Industrial Bank
6- And others

The summary of the facts is that the applicant, Penta Furniture and Furnishings Company (W.L.L.), submitted a request to the Bankruptcy Administration in its capacity as a (debtor) for a settlement against 1- Kuwait Finance House, 2- Ahli United Bank – currently Kuwait Finance House, 3- Warba Bank, 4- Al Mulla Finance Company, 5- Industrial Bank, and others.
Furthermore, the applicant company's business is capable of continuing, based on a technical study of its goods by Crowe Kuwait Consulting, an office registered with regulatory authorities. The debtor applicant has a plan to continue its activities, has future cash flows, and the creditors are holders of ordinary debts. The total bank debts amount to two million, five hundred eighty-nine thousand and forty-one dinars; the total supplier debts amount to one million, eight hundred forty-three thousand and eleven dinars; and the total employee debts amount to one million, four hundred thirty-four thousand, three hundred and sixteen dinars. There are debts to other parties amounting to one million, six hundred thirty-eight thousand and seven dinars. The book value of fixed assets is 650,357 dinars. There are methods to amortize the accumulated losses, and there is a financial study with a preventive settlement plan. It has submitted evidence and documents demonstrating its ability to continue operations and amortize its losses in a short period. It submitted document portfolios, the most important of which include (a resolution from an extraordinary general assembly, a letter classifying creditors, amounts due, and guarantees provided, a copy of the list of goods and assets, and financial statements for banks, suppliers, and employees). Consequently, the company became unable to pay its debts as a result of this impediment.
At the session of 26/12/2024, the applicant company's lawyer submitted a defense memorandum and a portfolio of documents demonstrating its ability to continue operations and pay its creditors' debts in light of the preventive settlement plan it submitted. The applicant company had outlined in its request a summary of the proposed preventive settlement and the agreements to be concluded with creditors regarding the settlement. It clarified its desire to be granted sufficient time to settle its outstanding debts in order to preserve the company's entity, the value of its assets, and the interests of its shareholders, while affirming its ability to fulfill all these debts.
At the session of 26/12/2024, a decision was issued by the Bankruptcy Judge (to address the Bankruptcy Committee to examine the request and provide an opinion thereon, stating the feasibility of the preventive settlement, assessing the debtor's financial situation and outstanding debts, stating whether or not precautionary measures should be taken, stating whether or not the debtor is capable of managing its business and funds on its own, and providing us with a detailed report on the matter, working as much as possible to complete this within the legal deadlines stipulated by the Bankruptcy Law, and stating the need to appoint an observer to examine the proposed preventive settlement, the measures taken, and the implementation of its proposal, and in the affirmative case, stating the value of the financial amount due to the observer, whether monthly or annually).
Whereas, a letter was received from the Bankruptcy Committee dated 20/3/2025 stating that it is unable to provide an opinion due to deficiencies in some details, which we refer to in detail to avoid repetition.
Whereas, the applicant's lawyer submitted three document portfolios, a flash memory, and a defense memorandum in response to the Bankruptcy Committee's report and insisted on his requests.
At the session of 14/4/2025, a decision was issued (to re-address the Bankruptcy Committee in light of the final defense memorandum submitted by the applicant, its document portfolios, and the attached flash memory, in response to the Bankruptcy Committee's letter, in order to "examine the request and provide an opinion thereon, stating the feasibility of the preventive settlement, assessing the debtor's financial situation and outstanding debts, stating whether or not precautionary measures should be taken, stating whether or not the debtor is capable of managing its business and funds on its own, and providing us with a detailed report on the matter, working as much as possible to complete this within the legal deadlines stipulated by the Bankruptcy Law, and stating the need to appoint an observer to examine the proposed preventive settlement, the measures taken, and the implementation of its proposal, and in the affirmative case, stating the value of the financial amount due to the observer, whether monthly or annually").

Whereas a letter was received from the Bankruptcy Committee <orig>لجنة افلاس</orig> dated 12/6/2025, which includes the acceptance in principle of a preventive settlement <orig>تسوية وقائية</orig> plan and the appointment of a supervisor <orig>مراقب</orig>, to which reference is made to avoid repetition.

And on 12/6/2025, a decision was issued to commence the preventive settlement <orig>تسوية وقائية</orig> procedures, stay all claims, prepare a preventive settlement proposal by the applicant, and form a creditors' committee, to which reference is made in detail.

Likewise, a decision was issued (The Bankruptcy Judge <orig>قاضي افلاس</orig> has decided: to appoint Ms. Rabia Saad Al-Muhanna <orig>رابعة سعد المهنا</orig> as a "supervisor <orig>مراقب</orig>" for Penta Furniture and Furnishings Company "L.L.C." <orig>شركة بنتا للأثاث و المفروشات "ذ.م.م"</orig> to follow up on the request for preventive settlement procedures and to oversee the company's financial affairs. She is entitled to a monthly salary of 1,000 K.D. (one thousand dinars) in accordance with the conclusion of the Bankruptcy Committee's <orig>لجنة افلاس</orig> report dated 12/6/2025, effective from today's date, 3/7/2025, until the final decision on this request is issued. This decision is to be published in the Official Gazette, and the Court Clerk's Office shall notify the litigants in this regard), to which reference is made to avoid repetition.

And in the session of 11/9/2025, the applicant's lawyer submitted a letter requesting (approval to extend the stay of judicial claims and enforcement actions taken against Penta Furniture and Furnishings Company L.L.C. <orig>شركة بنتا للأثاث والمفروشات ذ.م.م</orig> for a period of one month), to which reference is made to avoid repetition.

## Legal Basis:
Whereas it is established by the text of Articles (1 and 61) of the Bankruptcy Law <orig>قانون الإفلاس</orig> No. 71 of 2020 that: "For the purposes of applying the provisions of this law, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings indicated next to each: ... Stay of Claims <orig>وقف المطالبات</orig>: The suspension of any lawsuit or enforcement action filed against the debtor, whenever it relates to their assets or debts..." The issuance of a decision to commence preventive settlement procedures results in a stay of claims <orig>وقف المطالبات</orig> for a period of three months following the date of the decision. The Bankruptcy Judge <orig>قاضي الإفلاس</orig>, upon the debtor's request, may extend the period of the stay of claims one or more times, provided that each extension does not exceed one month, and in all cases, the total period of the stay of claims must not exceed six months. The Bankruptcy Administration, upon the debtor's request, shall provide them with a certificate of the stay of claims and its duration." And in accordance with Articles (1, 24, 25, 26, 55, 62, 70, 73) of the same law.

## Therefore, we have decided the following:
To extend the period of the stay of all judicial claims and enforcement actions taken against (Penta Furniture and Furnishings Company L.L.C. <orig>شركة بنتا للأثاث والمفروشات ذ.م.م</orig>) for a period of one month, starting from 13/9/2025. The Bankruptcy Administration shall notify the debtor companies, creditors, and the Bankruptcy Committee <orig>لجنة الإفلاس</orig> of this decision in accordance with Article (55) of the Bankruptcy Law <orig>قانون الإفلاس</orig> No. 71 of 2020 and publish it in the Official Gazette.

**Secretary**
**Bankruptcy Judge**

In accordance with Article (8) of the Bankruptcy Law <orig>قانون الإفلاس</orig>, decisions issued by the Bankruptcy Judge <orig>قاضي الإفلاس</orig> shall be considered enforceable instruments <orig>سندات تنفيذيه</orig> under this law. The Bankruptcy Administration shall affix the writ of execution <orig>الصيغة التنفيذية</orig> to them, and they shall be enforceable immediately upon issuance and without notification.

The Minister of Social Affairs and Family and Childhood Affairs

# Regulation on the Controls for Establishing Private Sports Clubs and Their System of Operation

## Article (1)
In the application of the provisions of this regulation, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings indicated next to each:
- **The Authority:** The Public Authority for Sport <orig>الهيئة العامة للرياضة</orig>.
- **The Board:** The Authority's Board of Directors.
- **The Competent Sector:** The Sports Affairs Sector.
- **The Competent Authority:** The Ministry of Commerce and Industry <orig>وزارة التجارة والصناعة</orig>, which issues company licenses.
- **The Permit:** The Board's approval for the establishment of the private club.
- **The Registration:** The entry of private clubs in the registers prepared for this purpose at the Authority.
- **The Concerned Federations:** The international federations and national federations for each sport.
- **The Private Club:** The entity established in the form of a company in accordance with the provisions of the Companies Law to practice one or more sports activities.
- **The Authorization to Practice the Activity:** The Authority's approval for the private club to begin practicing its sports activity.
- **The Regulations:** The organizational and procedural rules issued by the federation to regulate the sports activity.

## Article (2)
A natural or legal person may establish a private club, provided that the requirements of the concerned federations are met. The state shall not support it with any form of material or in-kind support.

## Article (3)
The private club aims to participate in sports competitions organized by the concerned federation and to encourage all age groups to practice sports, particularly the following:
1. Qualifying youth to join and participate in competitions and tournaments.
2. Developing and nurturing talented players in various age groups through sound scientific methods.
3. Preparing and qualifying players and raising their technical level.
4. Participating in sports competitions.
5. Teaching the basic skills of the licensed or permitted sports activity.
6. Applying modern systems and developing training programs.
7. Providing a safe and stimulating sports environment for practicing various sports activities.
8. Spreading sports culture and promoting a healthy lifestyle in the community.
9. Teaching the basic skills of the licensed or permitted sports activity.

## Article (4)
The procedures for establishing a private club may not be initiated before obtaining

2- A detailed plan of the club's headquarters, including an illustrative sketch (croquis) showing its affiliated sports facilities, in accordance with the requirements and specifications of the competent federation according to the type of sports activity.
3- Approval of the suitability of the sports facilities from the Institutional Services Sector (Facilities and Maintenance).
4- A proposed formation of the technical, administrative, and medical staff, in compliance with the conditions and requirements of the relevant sports federations according to the type of activity.
5- The legal title for the possession of the club's headquarters and its affiliated facilities, provided that they are suitable for practicing the sports activity for which the license is requested, in accordance with the conditions and requirements of the relevant sports federation, and that the lease or usufruct period is not less than the duration of the license granted to the club.
This is for the purpose of deciding on the aforementioned establishment application. The Authority may request the fulfillment of any documents it deems necessary from the applicant or others. The application shall be presented to the Board to make its decision thereon. In the event of approval, the Authority shall undertake the publication of the club's articles of association.

## Article (5)
The necessary technical conditions, specifications, and expertise must be available in the technical and administrative staff, as well as the medical staff and other support personnel, in a manner consistent with the requirements of the relevant federations and the nature of the sports activity to be practiced.

## Article (6)
The technical conditions, specifications, and standards must be met in the sports facilities in a manner consistent with the requirements of the relevant federation.

## Article (7)
The license to practice the sports activity shall not be granted until after obtaining the approval of the relevant federation and fulfilling all its requirements, including the availability of sports facilities in accordance with the approved technical conditions, specifications, and standards.

## Article (8)
The license to practice the sports activity shall be for a period of (4) years, renewable upon the request of the concerned parties before the expiration of the license period.

## Article (9)
The relevant federation shall be responsible for issuing the necessary permits for private sports clubs to participate in the competitions it organizes.

## Article (10)
The Authority shall prepare special registers for the registration of private sports clubs authorized to practice the activity, in which all the following data, in particular, shall be recorded:
1. The name of the club and the type of its activity.
2. The club's address and email.
3. The registration number in the companies register at the Ministry of Commerce <orig>وزارة التجارة</orig>, the license number, its date of issuance, and its duration.
4. The name of the responsible manager or the board of directors, as the case may be, and their qualifications, addresses, and email.
5. The names of the club's employees, including administrators, technicians, coaches, the manager responsible for the sports activity, the medical staff, and the names of supervisors for women's sports (if any).
6. The amendments made to the company's contract and their dates.

## Article (11)
The club must have a manager or chief executive officer with experience in the sports field, who must meet the following conditions:
1- Must be of good character and reputation.
2- Hold an accredited university degree.
3- Have a valid residency in the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> sponsored by the company if not a Kuwaiti national.

## Article (12)
Any permit issued for the establishment of a private sports club that is not acted upon within six months from the date it was granted shall be considered null and void. The Board of Directors may, upon the request of the concerned parties before the end of this period, grant one or more additional extensions, the total of which shall not exceed six months from the date of the original period's expiration. If the extension period expires without the activity commencing, the Board shall issue a decision considering the permit null and void, without prejudice to the provisions of the aforementioned Law No. (1) of 2016.

## Article (13)
Private clubs are obligated to join the competent sports federation in accordance with its articles of association. Clubs are not permitted to hold matches with foreign teams, whether inside or outside Kuwait, except after obtaining prior approval from the relevant sports federation and the competent administrative authorities.

## Article (14)
The Authority and the sports federations competent in each sports activity shall be responsible for overseeing the activities and sports facilities of private clubs to ensure
